title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy, with safeguards to protect unauthorized access. The Commissioner of Social Security transmits information on deceased individuals to federal and state agencies for benefits administration, with safeguards in place to prevent unauthorized use or disclosure. Agencies may reimburse the Commissioner for the costs of this cooperative arrangement. The Commissioner of Social Security can provide information on deceased individuals to federal agencies for specific purposes, with reimbursement for associated costs. This cooperative arrangement must not interfere with the Commissioner's duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies for specific purposes, such as operating the Do Not Pay working system or ensuring proper payments under a Federal program. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments, tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. The Commissioner of Social Security can enter into arrangements with States to provide information on deceased individuals for specified purposes, including crime prevention and benefit pension plan administration. The Commissioner of Social Security can use information on deceased individuals for statistical and research purposes, with safeguards in place to protect the data. The Commissioner of Social Security can utilize data on deceased individuals for statistical and research purposes, with protections in place. Amendments to certain sections of the Social Security Act will be repealed after 5 years, restoring the original provisions. Additionally, there is an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code in section 6103(d)(4). The provisions of the Social Security Act will be restored and revived, amending section 6103(d)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code to replace references to the Secretary of Health and Human Services with the Commissioner of Social Security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for use by Federal agencies, including State agencies, to assess accuracy, completeness, and accessibility. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, assessing accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability. A report will be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the enactment of the Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment, including a recommendation on extending agency access to death data from the Commissioner of Social Security. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the Act to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on improving data matching with death databases for beneficiaries and annuity recipients within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Social Security Act requires agencies to have access to death databases within 6 months of enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to help states and tribes provide death records electronically to the Federal Government within 1 year. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government. This plan may include recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. Additionally, a report to Congress on improving data matching regarding payments to deceased individuals must be submitted within 270 days of enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching on deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Additionally, an annual report is required within one year. The funded program aims to enhance data matching with the Federal Government regarding deceased individuals who receive benefits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit an annual report to Congress for five years, starting one year after the enactment of this section. Definitions for 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are provided in this section. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including individuals not receiving benefits. Elements of the plan include identifying extremely elderly individuals still alive according to records and improving policies for data accuracy verification. Improved policies and procedures for verifying the accuracy of Social Security Administration records, including identifying errors in the Numerical Identification System and death data, and allowing individuals to report potential errors. The Commissioner of Social Security shall implement improved policies and procedures to identify and correct errors in the Numerical Identification System and death data, including statistical analysis to estimate erroneous records, and make recommendations for legislation within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
